content: CAIRO - The U.S. is admitting defeat in Iraq with its withdrawal plan, said the purported leader of an al-Qaida-dominated insurgent umbrella group in Iraq in a message released Tuesday. Abu Omar al-Baghdadi, the leader of the Islamic State in Iraq, issued a 17-minute audio statement to militant Web sites, saying his plan of attack has been successful in forcing the U.S. to leave Iraq. Read the rest here: http://www.military.com/news/article/March-2009/iraqi-a...eclares-victory.html "A government big enough to give you everything you want, is strong enough to take everything you have." ~ Gerald Ford

title: Iraqi al-Qaida Leader Declares Victory

content: We knew this would happen. Of course it is the enemy saying that they defeated us by having us leave, but actually we signed an agreement saying we would be gone by 2011, which was setup by Bush. So is this actually defeat? "A government big enough to give you everything you want, is strong enough to take everything you have." ~ Gerald Ford

content: It's pretty hard to "win" a war of insurgency in the first place. If we stayed in Iraq for 100 years we'd probably still have at least a few nutcases running around with bombs. I'd say that if Iraq remains somewhat stable and friendly to the US over the next few decades and Iran doesn't gain too much influence, we can count that up as a "win".

title: Iraqi al-Qaida Leader Declares Victory

content: The invasion of Iraq is/was a total disaster for this country. If we get Iraq back to the condition it was pre-invasion, that would be a "success". But had we just left it alone, we'd have 4,200 of our guys back and many thousands more whole in mind and body. Despite the lies of the Bush Administration, AQ in 2003 was no more welcome there than they were here in the US. Saddam was a control freak; he ran a police state. Leaving him alone would much better have served our interests. Everything that has happened in Iraq was predicted, and predicted with authority to the Bush Administration. The Obama Administration would do well to heed the miitary aphorism: "Don't reinforce failure." Walt Captain USMCR

content: As Alexander once said, you have to go to the center of the fertile crescent to conquer the this land. Baghdad just happens to be the center of the Islam universe and even today the dominate force. Had one son in the Persian gulf destroying mines to protect the Iraqi ports and his USS Turner, (Cruiser) attacked on Thanksgiving day by Saddam's Air Force 1987, same year as the Stark got hit. Another relative, took his troops to Kuwait in 1991, that was fun and games. Now old Popsiq wants us to beleive this arse Hussein was a benevolent grandpappy looking out for the welfare of his subjects. Damn near had the atomic bomb at one time. Same as Iran today, once this leverage he would/could intimidate his neighbors and some nations in Europe. For all intensive purpose hold larger and more powerful nation as hostage. Even as weak as some would have us beleive Saddam or Ahmadinejad they both have held westerners in their jail, tortured, not like at Gitmo, I'm talking breaking bones, these folks were never to be seen again, telling the westerner nation "forget it". Happened just the other day. Now, if they can do that today, don't you think they would supply Fatah, Hamas, Hizbullah with more arms and bigger rockets even to a greater extent with bigger wars in the middle east, why doesn't it resonate with you that the more power they have, the more belligerant they will become. Maybe that's too deep for some. And, that is why we attack Saddam and fenced in Ahmadinejad, containing Al Qaeda. Quitting now would only encourage Osama and his jerks.

content: CAIRO - The U.S. is admitting defeat in Iraq with its withdrawal plan, said the purported leader of an al-Qaida-dominated insurgent umbrella group in Iraq in a message released Tuesday. Abu Omar al-Baghdadi, the leader of the Islamic State in Iraq, issued a 17-minute audio statement to militant Web sites, saying his plan of attack has been successful in forcing the U.S. to leave Iraq. Read the rest here: http://www.military.com/news/article/March-2009/iraqi-a...eclares-victory.html "A government big enough to give you everything you want, is strong enough to take everything you have." ~ Gerald Ford

content: It's pretty hard to "win" a war of insurgency in the first place. If we stayed in Iraq for 100 years we'd probably still have at least a few nutcases running around with bombs. I'd say that if Iraq remains somewhat stable and friendly to the US over the next few decades and Iran doesn't gain too much influence, we can count that up as a "win".

title: Iraqi al-Qaida Leader Declares Victory

content: The invasion of Iraq is/was a total disaster for this country. If we get Iraq back to the condition it was pre-invasion, that would be a "success". But had we just left it alone, we'd have 4,200 of our guys back and many thousands more whole in mind and body. Despite the lies of the Bush Administration, AQ in 2003 was no more welcome there than they were here in the US. Saddam was a control freak; he ran a police state. Leaving him alone would much better have served our interests. Everything that has happened in Iraq was predicted, and predicted with authority to the Bush Administration. The Obama Administration would do well to heed the miitary aphorism: "Don't reinforce failure." Walt Captain USMCR

The Obama Administration would do well to heed the miitary aphorism: "Don't reinforce failure." Walt Captain USMCR

content: quote: Originally posted by Anbar7: quote: Originally posted by WhiskeyPapa: The invasion of Iraq is/was a total disaster for this country. If we get Iraq back to the condition it was pre-invasion, that would be a "success". But had we just left it alone, we'd have 4,200 of our guys back and many thousands more whole in mind and body. So in this day and age if Hitler was around would you feel the same? He was a control freak and they did the same thing. And I have to disagree with you. There is a scarcity of proof that Saddam Hussein was 'bad' for America. It certainly was bad for him, and Iraqis. Even after the Gulf War, there is little more evidence that he was 'bad' for America than there is that Dopey was 'bad' for Seven Dwarves. He was light years away from being comparable to Hitler, other than in lip hair. Hitler may have 'sensitized' America considering it took almost 3 years of 'his' war and a declaration on his part, to aid the realization. Of late that sensitivity to 'bad guys' may have developed into an allergic hyperreaction to even hallucinated despots. This message has been edited. Last edited by: popsiq, Thu 19 March 2009 10:09 AM

content: I suppose to you he wasn't bad, try to explain that to his victims. Get them convinced, not me. Try to think bad a few years, on the days the troops took Baghdad and Saddam went into hiding. Think back about how the citizenry responded. If I remember correctly, they were elated. He also had a hard time honoring agreements if I remember correctly. Agreements he agreed to after the first Gulf War. So don't try to convince us he's bad, convince his former constituents. title: Iraqi al-Qaida Leader Declares Victory

content: As Alexander once said, you have to go to the center of the fertile crescent to conquer the this land. Baghdad just happens to be the center of the Islam universe and even today the dominate force. Had one son in the Persian gulf destroying mines to protect the Iraqi ports and his USS Turner, (Cruiser) attacked on Thanksgiving day by Saddam's Air Force 1987, same year as the Stark got hit. Another relative, took his troops to Kuwait in 1991, that was fun and games. Now old Popsiq wants us to beleive this arse Hussein was a benevolent grandpappy looking out for the welfare of his subjects. Damn near had the atomic bomb at one time. Same as Iran today, once this leverage he would/could intimidate his neighbors and some nations in Europe. For all intensive purpose hold larger and more powerful nation as hostage. Even as weak as some would have us beleive Saddam or Ahmadinejad they both have held westerners in their jail, tortured, not like at Gitmo, I'm talking breaking bones, these folks were never to be seen again, telling the westerner nation "forget it". Happened just the other day. Now, if they can do that today, don't you think they would supply Fatah, Hamas, Hizbullah with more arms and bigger rockets even to a greater extent with bigger wars in the middle east, why doesn't it resonate with you that the more power they have, the more belligerant they will become. Maybe that's too deep for some. And, that is why we attack Saddam and fenced in Ahmadinejad, containing Al Qaeda. Quitting now would only encourage Osama and his jerks.
